item.title: Quantum computing isn’t just about scaling
item.author: Murphy Yuezhen Niu
item.content:encoded:
The race to demonstrate quantum error correction often focuses on making ever-larger devices. A demonstration showing that splitting a surface-code logical qubit into two simpler repetition codes substantially reduces logical gate errors reminds us that advancing quantum computing does not hinge solely on scaling qubit numbers.

Murphy Yuezhen Niu

Nature Physics

item.title: Lattice surgery realized on two distance-three repetition codes with superconducting qubits
item.author: Ilya BesedinMichael KerschbaumAndreas Wallraff
item.content:encoded:
Quantum error correction codes protect quantum information, but running algorithms also requires the ability to perform gates on logical qubits. A lattice surgery scheme for fault-tolerant gates has now been demonstrated in a quantum repetition code.

Ilya BesedinMichael KerschbaumAndreas Wallraff

Nature Physics

item.title: China is betting on ‘optical’ computer chips — will they power AI?
item.author: Mohana Basu
item.content:encoded:
Semiconductor chips that process light rather than electricity could boost processing speeds and reduce energy use.

Mohana Basu

Nature

item.title: A cavity-array microscope for parallel single-atom interfacing
item.author: Adam L. ShawAnna SoperJonathan Simon
item.content:encoded:
A cavity-array microscope is realized using intra-cavity lenses to create a two-dimensional array of over 40 modes, each coupled to a single atom in free-space.

Adam L. ShawAnna SoperJonathan Simon

Nature

item.title: Optical switching of a moiré Chern ferromagnet
item.author: Xiangbin CaiHaiyang PanWeibo Gao
item.content:encoded:
Optical switching of a moiré Chern ferromagnet is demonstrated in twisted molybdenum ditelluride bilayers using continuous-wave circularly polarized light, paving the way for dissipationless spintronics and quantized Chern junction devices.

Xiangbin CaiHaiyang PanWeibo Gao

Nature

item.title: Low-power integrated optical amplification through second-harmonic resonance
item.author: Devin J. DeanTaewon ParkAmir H. Safavi-Naeini
item.content:encoded:
An integrated optical parametric amplifier on thin-film lithium niobate achieves more than 17 dB gain with less than 200 mW input power.

Devin J. DeanTaewon ParkAmir H. Safavi-Naeini

Nature

item.title: Optical control of integer and fractional Chern insulators
item.author: William HoltzmannWeijie LiXiaodong Xu
item.content:encoded:
Optical control of integer and fractional Chern insulators is demonstrated by circularly polarized optical pumping in tMoTe2.

William HoltzmannWeijie LiXiaodong Xu

Nature

item.title: Prethermalization by random multipolar driving on a 78-qubit processor
item.author: Zheng-He LiuYu LiuHeng Fan
item.content:encoded:
The existence of a long-lived, prethermal regime in many-body systems with tunable heating rates, driven by structured random protocols, is observed using a 78-qubit superconducting quantum processor.

Zheng-He LiuYu LiuHeng Fan

Nature

item.title: Intestinal macrophages modulate synucleinopathy along the gut–brain axis
item.author: Sebastiaan De SchepperViktoras KonstantellosTim Bartels
item.content:encoded:
Muscularis macrophages, housekeepers of enteric nervous system integrity and intestinal homeostasis, modulate α-synuclein pathology and neurodegeneration in models of Parkinson’s disease, and understanding the accompanying mechanisms could pave the way for early-stage biomarkers.

Sebastiaan De SchepperViktoras KonstantellosTim Bartels

Nature

item.title: Optical control over topological Chern number in moiré materials
item.author: O. HuberK. KuhlbrodtT. Smoleński
item.content:encoded:
Optical spin orientation of itinerant ferromagnets in twisted MoTe2 homobilayers is demonstrated, enabling control of topological Chern numbers with circularly polarized light.

O. HuberK. KuhlbrodtT. Smoleński

Nature

item.title: Ferromagnet-like binary switching of a Stoner–Wohlfarth antiferromagnet
item.author: Zhanshan WangYining XiangShiwei Wu
item.content:encoded:
CrPS4, a 2D van der Waals A-type antiferromagnet, is shown to exhibit ideal characteristics of Stoner–Wohlfarth antiferromagnets, such as ferromagnet-like binary switching rather than layer-by-layer flipping as in other 2D A-type antiferromagnets.

Zhanshan WangYining XiangShiwei Wu

Nature

item.title: Demonstration of low-overhead quantum error correction codes
item.author: Ke WangZhide LuDong-Ling Deng
item.content:encoded:
Quantum low-density parity-check error correction codes are anticipated to deliver high performance, but require long-range qubit–qubit interactions. Two of these error correction codes have now been successfully implemented on a superconducting device.

Ke WangZhide LuDong-Ling Deng

Nature Physics

item.title: From quantum computing to mRNA therapeutics: seven technologies to watch in 2026
item.author: Michael Eisenstein
item.content:encoded:
Nature’s round-up of innovations that are poised to make a splash in the year ahead.

Michael Eisenstein

Nature

item.title: Probing quantum mechanics with nanoparticle matter-wave interferometry
item.author: Sebastian PedalinoBruno E. Ramírez-GalindoStefan Gerlich
item.content:encoded:
Quantum interference of sodium nanoparticles, which can each contain more than 7,000 atoms at masses greater than 170,000 Da, is demonstrated.

Sebastian PedalinoBruno E. Ramírez-GalindoStefan Gerlich

Nature

item.title: Schrödinger’s cat just got bigger: quantum physicists create largest ever ‘superposition’
item.author: Elizabeth Gibney
item.content:encoded:
Record-breaking experiment shows that a cluster of thousands of atoms can act like a wave as well as a particle.

Elizabeth Gibney

Nature

item.title: Quantum spin resonance in engineered proteins for multimodal sensing
item.author: Gabriel AbrahamsAna ŠtuhecHarrison Steel
item.content:encoded:
A recently developed class of magneto-sensitive fluorescent proteins are engineered to alter the properties of their response to magnetic fields and radio frequencies, enabling multimodal sensing of biological systems.

Gabriel AbrahamsAna ŠtuhecHarrison Steel

Nature

item.title: AI and nuclear energy feature strongly in agenda-setting technologies for 2026
item.author: N/A
item.content:encoded:
Nature’s annual list of technologies to watch is a chance to celebrate progress and stimulate research into both opportunities and risks.

Nature

item.title: The biggest ‘Schrödinger’s cat’ yet — physicists put 7,000 atoms in superposition
item.author: Nick Petrić HoweBenjamin Thompson
item.content:encoded:
Quantum superposition gets supersized — plus, US science after a year of Trump.

Nick Petrić HoweBenjamin Thompson

Nature

item.title: Quantum effect observed for biggest objects yet
item.author: Tim Kovachy
item.content:encoded:
An experiment has broken the size record for an object exhibiting matter-wave interference — fuelling the debate about possible size constraints.

Tim Kovachy

Nature

item.title: Symmetry, microscopy and spectroscopy signatures of altermagnetism
item.author: Tomas JungwirthJairo SinovaLibor Šmejkal
item.content:encoded:
The symmetry, microscopy and spectroscopy signatures of altermagnetism are reviewed, and compared with traditional ferromagnetism and Néel antiferromagnetism, and magnetic phases with symmetry-protected compensated non-collinear spin orders.

Tomas JungwirthJairo SinovaLibor Šmejkal

Nature

item.title: Dynamical simulations of many-body quantum chaos on a quantum computer
item.author: Laurin E. FischerMatea LeahySergey N. Filippov
item.content:encoded:
Studying many-body quantum chaos on current quantum hardware is hindered by noise and limited scalability. Now it is shown that a superconducting processor, combined with error mitigation, can accurately simulate dual-unitary circuit dynamics.

Laurin E. FischerMatea LeahySergey N. Filippov

Nature Physics

item.title: Publisher Correction: A fault-tolerant neutral-atom architecture for universal quantum computation
item.author: Dolev BluvsteinAlexandra A. GeimMikhail D. Lukin
item.content:encoded:
Dolev BluvsteinAlexandra A. GeimMikhail D. Lukin

Nature

item.title: Trapping of single atoms in metasurface optical tweezer arrays
item.author: Aaron HolmanYuan XuSebastian Will
item.content:encoded:
Single strontium atoms are trapped in optical tweezer arrays generated via holographic metasurfaces, overcoming a critical barrier to realizing scalable neutral-atom quantum technologies.

Aaron HolmanYuan XuSebastian Will

Nature

item.title: Emergent topological semimetal from quantum criticality
item.author: D. M. KirschbaumL. ChenS. Paschen
item.content:encoded:
Examples of materials with non-trivial band topology in the presence of strong electron correlations are rare. Now it is shown that quantum fluctuations near a quantum phase transition can promote topological phases in a heavy-fermion compound.

D. M. KirschbaumL. ChenS. Paschen

Nature Physics

item.title: An electrically injected solid-state surface acoustic wave phonon laser
item.author: Alexander WendtMatthew J. StoreyMatt Eichenfield
item.content:encoded:
A completely solid-state, single-chip, microwave-frequency surface acoustic wave phonon laser can generate coherent phonons from thermal noise or resonantly amplify injected phonons using only a direct current bias field.

Alexander WendtMatthew J. StoreyMatt Eichenfield

Nature

item.title: Coherent nonlinear X-ray four-photon interaction with core-shell electrons
item.author: Ana Sofia Morillo-CandasSven AugustinGregor Knopp
item.content:encoded:
Using single broadband X-ray pulses from a free-electron laser on a gaseous neon target, coherent, nonlinear four-photon interactions with core–shell electrons is demonstrated, representing a strategy for multidimensional correlation spectroscopy at the atomic scale.

Ana Sofia Morillo-CandasSven AugustinGregor Knopp

Nature

item.title: Maximal device-independent randomness in every dimension
item.author: Máté FarkasJurij VolčičLaura Mančinska
item.content:encoded:
The laws of quantum mechanics make it possible to design device-independent security protocols that do not need trusted equipment. Now, explicit protocols are provided that achieve the optimal rate of device-independent random number generation.

Máté FarkasJurij VolčičLaura Mančinska

Nature Physics

item.title: Dynamic magneto-chiral instability in photoexcited tellurium
item.author: Yijing HuangNick AbboudFahad Mahmood
item.content:encoded:
Instabilities in chiral plasmas can amplify electromagnetic waves, raising the question of whether chiral solids behave similarly. Now a magneto-chiral instability is demonstrated in tellurium, observed as growing terahertz emission after photoexcitation.

Yijing HuangNick AbboudFahad Mahmood

Nature Physics

item.title: Exotic quasiparticles glimpsed in graphene
item.author: N/A
item.content:encoded:
Bilayer graphene has been used to observe robust interference patterns consistent with the presence of fractionally charged quasiparticles known as non-Abelian anyons. Demonstrating and controlling this interference is a crucial step towards harnessing these elusive quasiparticles as building blocks for fault-tolerant quantum computers.

Nature

item.title: Towards fibre-like loss for photonic integration from violet to near-infrared
item.author: Hao-Jing ChenKellan ColburnKerry Vahala
item.content:encoded:
Germano-silicate used as a building material for integrated photonics circuits substantially reduces optical losses, approaching levels comparable to those in optical fibres.

Hao-Jing ChenKellan ColburnKerry Vahala

Nature

item.title: Aharonov–Bohm interference in even-denominator fractional quantum Hall states
item.author: Jehyun KimHimanshu DevYuval Ronen
item.content:encoded:
This study reports coherent Aharonov–Bohm interference, including statistical phase contributions, in a Fabry–Pérot interferometer at two even-denominator fractional quantum Hall states in high-mobility bilayer-graphene van der Waals heterostructures is reported.

Jehyun KimHimanshu DevYuval Ronen

Nature

item.title: These women helped to shape quantum mechanics — it’s time to recognize them
item.author: Indianara Lima Silva
item.content:encoded:
An astute book redresses our collective perception of a field that became known as ‘boys’ physics’.

Indianara Lima Silva

Nature

item.title: Daily briefing: The human cells in our bodies that aren’t genetically ours
item.author: Flora Graham
item.content:encoded:
‘Microchimeric’ cells passed from your mother can challenge basic tenets of immunology. Plus, an experimental cancer vaccine that uses blood ‘cleaned’ with ultraviolet light and the evidence for trying ‘Dry January’.

Flora Graham

Nature

item.title: Self-induced superradiant masing
item.author: Wenzel KerstenNikolaus de ZordoJörg Schmiedmayer
item.content:encoded:
Superradiance is usually driven by light-mediated couplings, leaving the role of direct emitter interactions unclear. Now, it is shown that dipole–dipole interactions in diamond spins drive self-induced pulsed and continuous superradiant masing.

Wenzel KerstenNikolaus de ZordoJörg Schmiedmayer

Nature Physics

item.title: A chiral fermionic valve driven by quantum geometry
item.author: Anvesh DixitPranava K. SivakumarStuart S. P. Parkin
item.content:encoded:
Fermionic currents of opposing chirality can be spatially filtered without the need for a magnetic field using the quantum geometry of topological bands in single-crystal PdGa.

Anvesh DixitPranava K. SivakumarStuart S. P. Parkin

Nature

item.title: Interplay of orbital angular momentum and chirality
item.author: Dongjin OhHendrik BentmannRiccardo Comin
item.content:encoded:
Orbital angular momentum textures can drive orbital currents and enable applications in orbitronics. This Perspective shows how polarization-dependent angle-resolved photoemission spectroscopy can visualize orbital textures in momentum space.

Dongjin OhHendrik BentmannRiccardo Comin

Nature Physics

item.title: AI and quantum science take centre stage under Trump — but with little new proposed funding
item.author: Jenna Ahart
item.content:encoded:
The US administration is banking on public–private partnerships and an expanded workforce to deliver progress, but critics say that this strategy could be offset by other US policies.

Jenna Ahart

Nature

item.title: Electrically controlled nano-OLED metasurfaces
item.author: Jung-El RyuJeehwan Kim
item.content:encoded:
A nanostencil lithography technique enables fabricating arrays of green-emitting OLEDs with pixels as small as 100 nm and an external quantum efficiency of 13.1%.

Jung-El RyuJeehwan Kim

Nature Photonics

item.title: Are we living in a parallel universe? The strange physics of Stranger Things
item.author: Jenna Ahart
item.content:encoded:
Nature speaks to theoretical physicists to explore the real theories that inspired the hit series. Warning: contains spoilers.

Jenna Ahart

Nature

item.title: An 11-qubit atom processor in silicon
item.author: Hermann EdlbauerJunliang WangMichelle Y. Simmons
item.content:encoded:
An 11-qubit atom processor comprising two precision-placed nuclear spin registers of phosphorus in silicon is shown to achieve state-of-the-art Bell-state fidelities of up to 99.5%.

Hermann EdlbauerJunliang WangMichelle Y. Simmons

Nature

item.title: A modular quantum processor made using phosphorus atoms in silicon
item.author: N/A
item.content:encoded:
A high-performance silicon-based quantum processor has been developed in which the spins of nine phosphorus nuclei — divided into two groups, or registers — and two shared electrons act as quantum bits (qubits). The modular design of this 11-qubit processor opens the door to a scalable approach to building large, reliable quantum-computing processors.

Nature

item.title: Programmable 200 GOPS Hopfield-inspired photonic Ising machine
item.author: Nayem Al-KayedCharles St-ArnaultBhavin J. Shastri
item.content:encoded:
An architecture inspired by Hopfield networks based on a programmable, stable, room-temperature optoelectronic oscillator-based photonics Ising machine is introduced that can be used to efficiently address optimization and combinatorics problems.

Nayem Al-KayedCharles St-ArnaultBhavin J. Shastri

Nature

item.title: Visualizing interaction-driven restructuring of quantum Hall edge states
item.author: Jiachen YuHaotan HanAli Yazdani
item.content:encoded:
Scanning tunnelling microscopy is used to image pristine electrostatically defined quantum Hall edge states in graphene with high spatial resolution and demonstrate their interaction-driven restructuring.

Jiachen YuHaotan HanAli Yazdani

Nature

item.title: 3D nanolithography with metalens arrays and spatially adaptive illumination
item.author: Songyun GuChenkai MaoXiaoxing Xia
item.content:encoded:
A three-dimensional (3D) nanofabrication platform based on metalens-generated focal spot arrays is introduced to parallelize two-photon lithography beyond centimetre-scale write field areas, revealing the potential of 3D nanolithography towards wafer-scale production.

Songyun GuChenkai MaoXiaoxing Xia

Nature

item.title: Fusion and fission of particle-like chiral nematic vortex knots
item.author: Darian HallJung-Shen Benny TaiIvan I. Smalyukh
item.content:encoded:
Topologically protected vortex knots are shown to undergo fusion and fission, with electric pulses acting as a switch between the two processes. This might enable applications in electro-optics and photonics.

Darian HallJung-Shen Benny TaiIvan I. Smalyukh

Nature Physics

item.title: Optimal operation of hole spin qubits
item.author: M. BassiE. A. Rodríguez-MenaV. Schmitt
item.content:encoded:
Hole spin semiconductor qubits suffer from charge noise, but now it has been demonstrated that placing them in an appropriately oriented magnetic field can suppress this noise and improve qubit performance.

M. BassiE. A. Rodríguez-MenaV. Schmitt

Nature Physics

item.title: China leads research in 90% of crucial technologies — a dramatic shift this century
item.author: Xiaoying You
item.content:encoded:
The United States tops the remaining areas in an assessment of 74 technologies.

Xiaoying You

Nature

item.title: Quantum computing ‘KPIs’ could distinguish true breakthroughs from spurious claims
item.author: Elizabeth Gibney
item.content:encoded:
Researchers are devising ways to make new machines face off, without the hype.

Elizabeth Gibney

Nature

item.title: A super-conducting diode with ultimate efficiency and noise resilience at 77 K
item.author: N/A
item.content:encoded:
An electrical method is shown to reliably introduce nonreciprocal behaviour across a Josephson junction made of high-temperature cuprate superconductors, which then, under microwave irradiation, forms a ‘quantum superconducting diode’. The device is magnetic-field-free, works at a temperature of 77 K with a diode efficiency of 100%, and, owing to Shapiro steps that quantize the output voltage, has robust noise-filtering.

Nature Physics
